title: Modular Mercenary Trooper Kit (18mm scale)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Trying something new here. This isn't a printable model per se, but it includes the components I used to make my Mercenaty Trooper models. I've been asked for something like this enough times now that I went ahead and made a modifiable version for you all to tinker with as you please. Speaking of tinkering, you can also find the model here on TinkerCAD. This kit was modeled for our sci-fantasy tabletop RPG, Wayfarer: Things Beyond Wonder and for Wayfarer Tactics (coming soon), but can be used for whatever you like. If you make one (or a cool variant) I want to see pictures! We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested to help fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions.) Enjoy!

This is designed to fit in your car cupholder and hold the KBOX mini. It also works as a nice solid desktop stand. 
There are 3 versions: a barebones one, a barebones one with an extra cutout for a bottle holder (up to 25mm diameter), and a solid one. Not surprisingly, the solid one uses the least amount of filament if you print it with 20% infill or less.

This is landing gear for my tricopter, designed to zip tie onto the 1/2" square wooden booms.
Printed in Nylon (excuse my terrible print quality, still learning the nylon) I tried this with ABS, but they mostly shattered on the first hard landing. The nylon seems to be getting similar nice, bouncy performance to the huge bent up zip tie I was using previously, but I wanted to do something that looked slightly less ghetto. The little slant braces are designed to help manage cables, or can be cut off easily if they're in the way.

This part is designed to allow your thingomatic to rest a little bit higher from the electronics to avoid cable strain from confined spaces while providing a stable footing. This is still being refined I will update the files as the design is changed. V2 - Solid (Takes less time but uses a lot of plastic)
V3 - Hollow (Takes more time but uses less and is lighter) EDIT: If you make a derivative please attribute the original to me.

Each piece will take some time to print, the original took 3 hours. In replicatorg scale the part about 7.6 times bigger(adjust based on first print result). 1.Print 4 Corner Feet.
2.Seperate Wooden Electronics Base from build box.
3.Rest build box in feet slots.
4.Optional - Screw everything to the feet.

title: Tablet Holder for Bicycles on Trainers

description.text:
This is a tablet holder for bicycles on trainers. Primary goal for the design was ease of mounting. Only a few O rings or thick rubber bands are required for mounting on handlebars. Due to variances in design of handlebars and stems, this may not work for all combinations.
There is clearance for power connection in the bottom middle of the Pad Holder Base. For securing this to the handlebar, I used Qty 2 of 220 size rings per side, its what I had lying around. Sizes you'll need will vary on the handlebar and stem size. There are three areas for O-Rings, two on the handlebar and one on the stem. I really needed just two on the handlebar, I didn't need one of the stem. For hardware, you'll need Qty 4 thumb screws (1/4"-20 x 1"L) from McMaster Carr P/N 91185A925 and 4 nuts. As a nice to have, I used Foam Tape from McMaster Carr P/N 8694K92. These are 1/8" thick by 1 1/2" wide which will fit the rectangular grooves on the base part. This just provides a soft surface for your tablet. Print Qty 2 of Pad Holder Arm, 1 of other parts.

title: Duplicator i3 USB cord strain relief

description.text: This thing mounts to the side of the control box and provides a place to zip tie the USB cord so it doesn't get pulled out while printing. You can use the original screws to mount. There is also a square shaped "wing" that is designed to nest along the front side of the left Z column. When pushed up in this position it holds the filament spool in the correct location. This is for the original control box so I don't know if any changes to the hole pattern have been made with newer boxes. If you have your control box on the right side of the printer you should be able to mirror the model and use it on the other side of the box assuming the hole pattern is symmetrical.  Route the USB cable thru the notch near the square "wing" part and then lay it into the bevel at the back of the part so you can push your control box over to touch the printer without the cord interfering.

When you receive boards are sure to double and triple check the contacts and pads for bridging before you solder your pins on and after. The picture is of two pololu's that i bought for making a reprap three worked fine and the fourth shorted out and caught fire. They were all run through the same test on the same board receiving signal from my cupcake CNC and they were all plugged in to the driver carrier correctly. 
Check all of your boards before you turn them on no matter who you get them from. If you do not have a smoke detector in your workshop get one!

title: Heat The Print Bed (without a heater) Attempt #2

description.text:
This is a heating alternative for the Printrbot Simple 1403 with E3Dv6 hot end (might work with standard UBIS).
Are your print edges curling, prints coming off the bed in low temperatures? Although sunny Singapore doesn't have that problem, my prints go haywire whenever someone switches on the air conditioner and sets the thermostat below 25C. 
This simple deflector harnesses the exhaust heat from the hot end and directs it onto the print bed. Overall it has achieved a 3 degree Celcius increase, not much but enough to keep large prints flat and small ones on the bed without a massive overhaul to add a heat bed.
The open vent allows the cool exhaust to blow through and not onto the bed.

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Notes: I printed with a 2 layer raft as it prints high but thin.
Support suggested, unless you're very confident of your bridge settings.

title: Fallout New Vegas Veteran Ranger Helmet and Mask

description.text:
The mask, helmet, sensor cluster are based upon a pepakura unfold by MTKKTM (AKA KTM\ or KirkTrekModeler). The pepakura unfold can be found here: http://mtkcardcraft.blogspot.com.br/2013/05/fallout-new-vegas-ncr-combat-ranger.html The breather and helmet box pieces are my design. I added a flange to the bottom to have a flat surface to sit on the build plate that is to be removed or contoured later so your neck fits. I didn't make everything perfect and smooth, because you're a war hardened, grizzled, warrior who has seen some shit! I have not printed the final version of everything yet. I'm sure there will be changes and updates as I do. Parts to Print:
-Mask
-Mask Tube Base (optional as cover art has the breather tube on the right side, but in-game model does not, thus why I left it seperate)
-Amp (I recommend the amp made by crin here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:403788)
-Breather Body
-Breather Top (made one with a screen as well as one without, If you use without and add your own screen, I provided an optional inner ring to be pressed inside the breather to hold the screen in place)
-Tail (back of mask assembly)
-Helmet
-Helmet Box
-Helmet Box Pieces
-Antenna Find you some lenses and tint them red or green
Assemble
Sand
Paint
Weather
Wear
Be awesome!

author: HenniC4

description.text:
Was tired of a warped bed and having to tape a piece of glass to the bed constantly.  Occasionally and more often on longer prints the tape would come loose and the glass plate would shift, ruining the print.  I then decided to order a 1/4 x 7-1/4 x 11-1/2 inch piece of annealed glass with a flat grind on it all the way around.  These are the pieces that hold the bed to the Y-axis carriage.  This bed has improved my setup, cleaning, over all printing tremendously.
11/19/15  I just included a sketchup file of the holder in case those of you want to edit it to your specific bed materials size and shape.  Both the front and back piece are in the one file, they are asymmetric pieces.

Printer:

QU BD TwoUp

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

50%

Notes: I designed this a while ago(August 2015), found two files labeled front and back, they may be mirror images of each other.

Glass orders don't have tight tolerences. I ordered the glass to be 1/4 x 7 1/4 x 11 1/2 inches.
The dimensions of the actual pieces can be off by up to 1/8 inch.
I used electrical tape to cushion the glass in the plastic and to give friction so it won't slide in the plastic holders. More or less may be needed based on the actual size of your glass plate.
The glass order was about $45 for one custom piece and $49 for two of them(both prices include the shipping), I ordered two just in case I broke one. Though the tolerances aren't great, the two pieces of glass are actually exactly the same, so I can interchange them with no problems.

comments.text:
http://www.onedayglass.com
It came quickly, I think it was less than a week, and was packages securely. Like I said, it cost roughly the same for two as it did for one.

    E3D Chimera w/ V6 and Volcano Hot Ends.
    E3D Cyclops
    E3D V6 w/ V6 and Volcano Hot Ends.

  • Carriages supported:
    C Bot - Core XY
    Prusa i3 variants with vertical X Carriage.

  • Extruders supported:
    Bowden
    E3D Titan

  • Probes supported:
    Servo / arm
    Inductive
    BL Touch

  • C Bot exclusive
    Endstops supported
    YL-99
    Keyes
    Generic mini switch

  • Prusa i3 variants - X Carriage mount, customizable to fit nearly any 4 bolt X Carriage. eg; i3, rework, 23mm spacing, 30mm spacing, whatever, you pick the spacing, it builds the design.

  • Inductive sensor mount: customizable to the size of your sensor and how high it should be mounted.

  • Servo mounting bracket: customizable to whatever size servo you have, how much horizontal clearance it has and you choose the side of the cold end it sits on

  • Blower fan mount: Defaults to 51x51x15, but customizable if you know the size and screw point locations. You can also customize the horizontal and vertical angle, how far out the fan mount extends, how thick the mount is, how wide the connection point is, etc.....

  • Fan duct:
    Simple prototype. This is automatically designed based on the criteria you choose, fan angles, hot end, fan mount depth, etc...
     Full 360 prototype. This very very experimental at the moment, print at your risk.

  • Z Probe arm: This auto sizes according to the servo dimensions and placement. You can set activation distance among other settings.

  • Easy-ish printing: Trying to ensure the generated models are easily printable without support. eg; All nut traps are closed and need to be physically opened before use. This is done so printers are bridging instead of air printing the back side of a nut trap.
    • I've started working on the back log of updates, here they are in no particular order.
  • Move hot end to the end of the carriage instead of middle. - Allows for more compact layout and shrinking of carriage. - Done!
  • Move probe to same carriage side as hot end. - Reduce overall chassis footprint needed. More Accurate probing. - Done!
  • Shrink overall width of carriage. - Reduce overall chassis footprint needed. - Done for C Bot.
  • Fan duct - Finally finish the work to build an auto generated duct, perhaps similar to the design @AK Eric designed. - Done!
  • Add option to mount LEDs.
  • Add direct drive options. - @Carl Feniak 's design and @Elmo Clarity's for the Titan extruder.
    • BOWDEN USERS: Do yourself a favor and use clips like the ones below. This will reduce the amount of retraction needed and more importantly provide for better consistentency and accurate prints matching or approaching direct drive setups. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:936611 TO DO Still:

  • Add bearing support for round bar style mounts. This should allow you replace the X Carriage + hot end mount with just the hot end mount with integrated bearing holders. This will reduce wait and smaller XY / X carriage.

  • Add additional fan mount placements and integrate fan mount directly into carriage. Further reduce the size of overall carriage and parts.

  • Clean up code, drop customizer support in order to make code cleanup easier. No one uses the customizer anyway. Split up code correctly into separate files. - Coming eventually... :)

  • Add more hot ends: drop a comment with more suggestions.

  • Add more carriages: which one should I add next?

  • Add dual hot ends and any variant. Kicking around the idea of attempting to code up a system that automatically aligns disparate hot ends for dual extrusion.

  • Add dremel / rotary cutting tool mount

  • Add camera mount: not sure how practical this is, but the idea came to me this morning. This is a long shot.... mainly because I'm trying to keep the moving weight as low as possible.
    • Be aware that this is very very much a work in progress. Please feel free to provide feedback and suggestions or even better yet, help out by contributing code. :) This is my first openscad project and what I am using to teach myself openscad, so the code is not terribly efficient or clean yet, but, it works. I've removed the sample STLs. Development is fairly quick and it's too much of a hassle to update all the various sample files. USE THE CUSTOMIZER to produce a hot end mount for your printer. If you have questions, please feel free to ask. This is GPL and the source code is also available vit GitHub. Contributors very welcome!
    GitHub repository: https://github.com/croadfeldt/Roadfeldt_3d_hczf_mount Watch the GitHub page for details on code changes. Updates will occur their far more often than they will here.

This would have put the BL touch below the hotend. I believe the change I made sould fix that, please test and let me know since I don't have a BL touch. Thinking about getting one though. Hmmm.... ** 6-25-2017 - I am halting development of this for the time being. The code is overly complex and is in need of a rewrite, most likely in a different language than OpenSCAD. This is not a knock against OpenSCAD, in fact it's doing great. But the language simply was not intended to be doing what I am doing with it. To that end, it's become an unruly little thing and needs some tempering, most likely in python which exports OpenSCAD code. This should allow me to properly modularize and objectify objects which in turn makes each component easier to create, modify and inject into the design intelligently. There is no ETA on this work as of yet. Until then, most likely there will be no more changes to this script by me. The bugs it has, it's going to have to make peace with. comments.text:
Hello,
I am working on building a C-Bot with an E3D Chimera with dual volcano heat blocks and I got a few questions. Does this support the E3D Chimera with dual volcano heat blocks with dual E3D Titan extruders for direct drive? I need to use direct drive to allow the printer to actually take advantage of the dual volcano setup.
comments.author: BinaryNightowl

comments.text: This supports a chimera with volcano blocks, but not dual titan. I believe you can do one titan and one bowden. FWIW - I have a chimera, it prints fabulously with a dual bowden setup. The reason I went with a titan on my c-bot was for flexible filaments mainly, though I can do them on my chimera bowden setup with the proper settings and a little luck.
comments.author: BinaryNightowl

comments.text: I do want to print some exotics but this is not my reasoning for wanting direct drive. In Tom's review of the volcano he said that the speed that it could print at became limited by the extruder, and in his Bondtech extruder review he said it allowed him to increase the print speed that his volcano achieved. Also this blog here ( http://www.akeric.com/blog/?p=3497 ) said that he had problems with bowden and retraction. I plan to use 0.4, 0.6, 0.6, and 0.8 mm nozzles when I need precision, and 0.8, 1.0 and 1.2 mm nozzles when I need to get huge prints done. My concerns are that a bowden setup will now allow for me to print at high enough speeds and loss of print quality with volcanos. Are these concerns legit or am I over complicating things.
comments.author: croadfeldt

comments.text: Ha! I know that blog, akeric and I are members of the same C-Bot google group, plus my printer was based on his original build of the C-Bot. He and I have talked about this exact debate along with many others. In the end, the direction you go in will have it's pros and cons regardless. My point was simple to say don't preclude a bowden setup simply because it's a bowden setup. A direct drive setup has it's own set of issues, weight being a major one, especially if you are looking to go with dual direct drive extruders and a chimera / cyclops. Your acceleration and top speeds will be limited by the weight of the carriage. If precision and speed is your goal, than a single extruder with a lightweight pancake / midsize motor and a v6 / volcano is the way to go. If you want to go with multiple material printing, then a 2 in to 1 or 4 into 1 bowden setup is ideal as it introduces the least amount of weight.
comments.author: BinaryNightowl

comments.text: Thank You for getting back to me, Sounds good but I am not sure which setting should I adjust, C Bot Xy Bar Height Height or XY Bar or C Bot Wheel Offset From Bar?
comments.author: croadfeldt

comments.text: Bar height is the height of the aluminum extrusion used for the xy bar. On a 20x40 V-Slot that would be 40. The Wheel Offset is the distance from the top of the xy bar to the center of the wheel. This allows for different wheel and extrusion combos. The default is for a 20x40 V-slot with OpenBuilds mini wheels, even though the description stating otherwise is wrong.

Hi there,
This is my Darth Vader inspired lamp. I used a typo LED light which comes in two in a box for $19 Australian I used Darth Vader black filament of course and about 3 hours in I changed the roll for a little bit of red then I went back to the black.
That touch is up to you but I think it brings the devil out of the lamp with that colour. There is also a little cylinder which I glue to the end of the typo light which has a battery compartment near the bulb. the light turns on when you pull the cord so i thought I would feed the light from underneath and the cylinder works as a stopper if you want it that way.
Otherwise have nothing, the hole is a tight fit so I had to warm up the lamp hole with boiling water then I fitted the typo light and its tight in there now. I hope you enjoy it. when you make it make sure to add photos.
thank you!!

title: Nikko's Jet Gale 91 upgrade to a mabuchi 540

description.text:
WARNING: This proyect has 3d printed parts spinning at high speeds, if you print it , please be careful.
Here is an upgrade of my childhood toy, a nikko jet gale 91, at the third foto is the comparasion of the original motor and the mabuchi motor, a very cheap option to do some Maker proyects like this one.
it works fine with the original propeller, it uses about 10A, which is half the potential of the 540 motor, so i have designed two news propellers, both have the same input angle and output angle, but one of them has 3 blades and the another one has 5 blades, i don´t have tested the 5-blade-prop because with the 3-blade-prop the speed has considerably increased. the power consumption with the 3-blade-prop is around 22A. But my propeller has some disadvantages, it makes the motor to do a lot of torque and it makes the boat to heel over at high speeds, what ends in a constant turn to the right at high speeds, it can be correct but the cornering to the left is worse than to the right. another disadvantage that i have seen with my prop is that sometimes when you go through a wave, a bubble goes to the prop and the motor speeds up without pushing the boat forward. to solve this problem is to easy as taking gas out and giving another time gas. here are two videos of the boat working: with original prop:
https://youtu.be/Nn-YDuAk7O0 with my designed one:
https://youtu.be/jxUaev8fVYs
here you can see the disadvantages described before.

It's a rainbow made with a printed holder, vinyl tubing, food coloring, and silicone sealant.  The OpenSCAD file is parametric so you can use different tubing diameters and the depth of the holes.  It will also spit out the theoretical lengths of tubing needed for each band.  The pictured printed part is big enough that I had curling with PLA, kinda motivating me to upgrade to heated bed.

(1) Print the holder.
(2) Cut tubing to lengths indicated in the text output of the OpenSCAD script.  Better to err on the side of cutting too long a piece.
(3) Insert the smallest piece into the holder.  If it seems too long snip off little bits at a time until it looks right to you.  Then insert the next largest tube.  Make sure its top is flush with that of the smaller tube.  If it is not cut off a little at a time until it is.  Continue until all the empty tubes are inserted.
(4) Filling the tubes: I tried many sealing methods. The easiest I have found so far is to use a hot glue gun to make a plug on one side, fill, and make a plug on the other side.  If using thin tubes like in those pictured, you may have some difficulty filling the closed tube.  The 'trick' is to not drop in enough liquid at once to block the entire cross section of the tube.  If you do surface tension will hold the bead of water in the tube and you'll need to flick the tube to break it up.  Getting zero bubbles when you plug the 2nd side requires a little technique.  What worked best for me is trying to extrude the almost into a tube wall, so it would flow around the sides leaving room for air to escape until the last possible moment.  Even if you get a few bubbles, you can trap them at the base of the rainbow afterwards by holding it upside down and flicking the offending tube.
DISCLAIMER: By building this rainbow you agree to not hold Trevor Law liable for anything bad that happens to you.  I was somewhat wary of using hot glue on PVC tubing because toxic gases can be released, but I asked my engineering technology teacher and he said it's probably okay as long as it is only heated for short time.  I felt it was an acceptable risk for me but I provide no guarantees that step 4 here is safe or healthy.  I highly recommend you wear goggles or other eye protection while applying the hot glue.  When the glue is applied on the second side to close off the tube, it is substantially hotter than the boiling point of the water it comes into contact with.  Although I didn't have any issues with this at the time of this writing, it does sizzle and spattering of hot glue/water/pvc is possible.
(5) Insert the tubes back into the holder.  Then look at it for awhile.  If you are building this and want more detail on something, please drop a comment.

comments.text: If they make them in an appropriate form for fitting inside vinyl tube let me know as I am interested for other things for work.  That would work best with a strongly diffusing/translucent plastic so you can't see discrete LEDs.  That is an awesome idea.

this a ball jointed foot for your Combiner Wars, or any other 5mm peg compatible transformers gestalts. it was heavily inspired by the original g1 defensfor foot. it comprises of two modules - the foot body (two versions with minor detail changes) and a ball joint module. the latter one being separate, so you don't have to bin the whole thing if the peg should brake. or, you could use it in your own designs. a couple of tips. the ball joint is a tricky print, to get some trouble out of the way i have cut off the top. it will make it much easier to print (peg facing up) , no supports, no stringing, no scarring etc. print with 100% infill, and with PLA - print the sphere without fans, as they will make the layers to curl up. if necessary print slower (i print mine at 30-40mm/s) just be advised, that slower print will translate into bigger filament flow resulting in the ball being slightly bigger. this is why i include 3 sizes of balls - 14.8, 14.7 and 14.6 - so that you can easily test which one will fit.
once the sphere is done turn the fans fully on to get a nice and smooth peg. also print one object at a time to avoid strinnging and scarring. be advised that the ball should be smoothed/sanded a bit before you squeeze it in to the socket. i do the smoothing by putting the ball into a battery drill and rotating it against a sanding sponge (pic attached). try to get as small gradient as possible. there is no need to smoothen the socket inside as long as the ball is even and smooth. the ball should pop in the socket with only a little bit force - if you need to push it really hard, or worse - against the floor or so - this means the ball still needs some filing down. try printing all balls and getting the best result for your printer and filament. NOTE - IF YOU MAKE THE JOINTS TOO TIGHT OR TRY TO FORCE A JAMMED JOINT TO MOVE USING A COMBINER WARS FIGURE PORT YOU ARE LIKELY TO DAMAGE THE PORT IN YOUR FIGURE!!! Best to print all balls, smoothen them and do the socket fitting tests starting from the smallest one. depending on your printer quality you also might want to smoothen the sides of the socket module and the socket it goes to in the foot body. it should go in with some friction, but excess friction will make it hard to remove should anything brake. to get it out simply take one of your damaged ball joint sockets (don't worry, i destroyed some 20 or 30 of these before i got the thing running :) the ball joint should provide enough friction to pose the gestalt on one foot only (you will however have a problem with the original joints collapsing :) as for printing of the foot it's up to you, i print 0.8 mm shell and 10% infill, perimeter after infill and "one at a time". hope you enjoy it. any questions or requests - comment or message me. ps. i dont know why but the stl exported upside down, nevertheless it is the same foot as pictured, just need to rotate it in slicer. Ps.2 adres 2 pictures of different feet prototype with same ball joint to ilustrate its abilities. Note - getting the joint that sort of performance will reqire a bit of trail and error. EDIT - Added four files - all with FINAL in name - one socket with corrected socket inlet and smoothened bottom for easier insertion into feet and 3 balls with a bit thicker peg and and modified connection between peg-ball. The balls have a diameter of 14,7; 14,75 and 14,8 and that should work on most of accurate printers. also it is better to print it in abs than pla as it is more flexible. i print all my balls at maximum infill. I have also noticed that sockets with low infill ale a bit more loose than with a dense infill (ABS printed), check how Your machine behaves.

This thing holds a small amount of water in several tiny containers.  It is for the soaking of oboe reeds, before scraping and playing.   
It has two advantages that egg cups lack: It's a bit harder to knock it over, and the reeds of several players are kept separate, reducing the odds of someone catching something!

Print it 100% ABS, any colour.
Then add water, and reeds!

description.text: This is a new shade for my Candlestick lamp (see link above for what this piece is derived from - a twist on maglite operated lamp).  The shade was designed as a stylized, almost toony candle shape meant to evoke the idea of a candle and not to reproduce the real life shape.  Some spirals sculpted into the side, inverted perspective shaping, and the suggestion of the wick complete the look.
Print this part, and then insert it into the cup of the candstick lamp instead of the pointed taper style shade that is included with the original design.

For those who just can't get enough of burr puzzles...
This puzzle's design pulled from the now defunct IBM research page. It was categorized under General higher level burr puzzles. This is a level 10 puzzle with a unique solution. These pages are still available through internet archives, see the links at the end of the wikipedia page. Note: I rotated piece 4 to turn an overhang into a bridge. This built cleanly on my cupcake with minimal sagging at the default size 6.
While I found the Philippe Dubois burr slightly challenging, I found this one much harder.
I have uploaded the puzzle file for Burrtools, see Burr Tools on sourceforge which can animate assembly too.

I like to print the pieces individually, so I have included stls for both a tray of all pieces and each separate piece.
The scad file requires the burr module this object is derived of.
Assembly instructions on the research page above are probably more complicated than necessary, and assembling by adding one piece at a time is a bit difficult, as it unstable until the last piece is in and the first slide accomplished. I found it easier to assemble this burr by assembling the pieces as two groups of 3 and then merging those. The groups I chose were 135 and 246. There may still be more optimal ways to assemble it, and a possible shortcut/cheat involving rotating piece 4 into its slot.

remixed_from.author: bsthomps
remixed_from.title: Prusa Spool Holder and Support for 1kg Spools

description.text:
Modified spool support arm for Reprappro Prusa Mendel.  No fiddling with nuts or undoing screws, just lift the spool out!  
Update 20/7/2013: I have added an extended version of the arm (spool_arm_v2), which is 20mm longer.  
I really liked bsthomps' spool holder, although it's for an earlier version of the reprap pro than mine, and you have to unscrew things to remove the spool. I've tweaked the design so that you can just lift the spool axle out of the top of the arm, and I've strengthened the arm around the rear support.

Print it and clip it on.  It's designed for an 8mm axle, but you may need to tweak the axle support a bit with a knife or a drill bit so that the axle slips out easily. 
Also print the spool hub supports from bsthomps' thing.

comments.text: I made the V2 version, and with the spool that I have, same as above, it does not foul the extruder - there is about 2cm of space, even worst case. I use a RepRapPRO Mendel.
comments.author: krats

comments.text: A neat sturdy design. I have the exact same cardboard spool but it (only just) fouls the extruder, even with some spool 'centers' added. Would be great if they could be a little bit longer. I have made some hook on extension brackets, if they are any good I'll post the model. I guess they probably fit a regular spool better. Either way, a good useful design, especially for those with RepRapPRO Mendel machines, thanks for posting it.
comments.author: MattCook

description.text: Had my dual monitors tilting and sagging due to a poor monitor mount. Created a simple block to support the monitor and hold it up. Printed 3 of them to support both monitors on the ends and the middle.

Turn your Jeep TJ front speaker from a 4"x6" to a 5.25".
Mounts to the factory location using original hardware. Mount speaker using M3 screws.
It's a tight fight on my '98 TJ. I assume it will fit 97-02 TJs also, not sure.
This single file will work on the driver or passenger side, just make sure the letters "outside" are pointing to the outside of the Jeep aka flip it 180 degrees. I designed this personally and I am providing it for you to use for free, please don't sell it as part of the licensing agreed to upon downloading. It takes time to make stuff.

comments.text:
thats great!

Thanks Dude
comments.author: CCFLY

comments.text: Nice work, however, if your plate covers the hole completely... it will sound a ton better, you'll ave a much better low end response. Even just using duct tape to seal the back of the speaker from the front will stop what's called "Rarefaction". This is when the sound waves from the back side of the cone circle around and crash into the sound waves from the front side of the cone, effectively cancelling out a good amount of low end. It will also force more sound to be directed out from the front side of the cone, effectively raising your dB level from these front speakers. Just a tip, I've done audio for 30 years, have many 1st place SQ+ 600w and up wins, 2nd place in IASCA world finals SQ+ 600w and up.

title: Convert a hand coffee grinder into a battery powered one

description.text:
This thing will allow you to attach a Hitachi DB3DL Cordless Screwdrivers to a Zassenhaus Guatemala hand grinder.
I find that my Zassenhaus grinds coffee much better than my 110V AC powered grinder.  It also lets me grind specific weights of coffee bean more easily than with my regular grinder.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2X

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes: The fill and resolution are not that important, you will need supports, and I found the raft helps a lot.

• Hitachi DB3DL Cordless Screwdrivers
  • Zassenhaus Guatemala hand grinder
  • 5.5 mm socket to 1/4"
  • 1/4" to hex adapter
    • Print the part, ensure that the 5.5 mm socket can move freely in the provided hole, otherwise drill out the hole such that it can move freely, yet not fall out of the 3D printed part.

title: Ping Pong Paddle with replaceable paddle.

description.text: This paddle was designed so that the user can replace either the handle with different designs, or replace a worn handle. The paddle can either be printed and have rubber added or made by attaching the screw section to an existing paddle face. The latter is shown in the pictures. The washer was added to help with making the screw attachment flush.
